CATALOGUE •JAPANESE PRINTED BOOKS AND MANUSCRIPTS IN THE LIBRARY OF THE BRITISH MUSEUM BY ROBERT KENNAWAY DOUGLAS KEEPER OF THE DEPARTMENT OF ORIENTAL PRINTED BOOKS AND MSS. PRINTED BY ORDER OF THE TRUSTEES OF THE BRITISH MUSEUM LONDON: SOLD AT THE BRITISH MUSEUM ; AND BY MESSRS. LONGMAN'S & CO., 39, PATERNOSTER ROW ; BERNARD QUARITCH, 15, PICCADILLY ; ASHER & CO, 13, BEDFORD STREET, COYENT GARDEN ; KEGAN PAUL, TRENCH, TRUBNER & CO., PATERNOSTER HOUSE, CHARING CROSS ROAD ; and HENRY FROWDE, OXFORD UNIVERSITY PRESS, AMEN CORNER. 1898. [All rights reserved .] THE GETTY CENTER LIBRARY PREFACE. The Japanese Books and Manuscripts which form the subject of the present Catalogue have been brought together during many years and under various circumstances. The first contributions to the Library were contained in the Sloane, Cottonian, Harleian, and Banksian Libraries, but the first collection of any size or importance was that acquired by purchase from Herr von Siebold in July, 1868. In 1882 the magnificent collection of Works on Art, etc., gathered by Mr. William Anderson was bought ; and two years later a collection of Books, printed at early periods in Japan and Korea, was purchased from Mr. (now Sir) E. M. Satow, who subsequently presented a number of other works of the same character. A further collection of Japanese Books in 1,284 volumes was purchased from Mr. William Anderson in 1894. In addition to these acquisitions, works have been purchased and presented in the usual course, until at the present time the Museum possesses upwards of 5,000 separate Japanese Works. The entries in this Catalogue are arranged under the names of the Authors, when these occur, in alphabetical order, In cases where the Author’s name does not appear on the title-page or in the body of the Work, the Book is catalogued under the name of any person or place which forms part of the title. But if no such name is to be found, the subject of the Work or the principal word in the title has been taken as a heading. There is always a difficulty in transliterating Oriental words and names, and this difficulty is vastly increased in the case of Japanese owing to the system of writing adopted in Japan. As a rule, the names of Authors and the titles of their Works are given in Chinese characters. If these characters had fixed and definite values they would not present any serious difficulty. But the Japanese attach to each written character three or more sounds. Thus, a character may in the first place be taken as representing the native word which it signifies : for example, the Chinese character ffi Sinice, Shan, “ a mountain,” is to be pronounced Yama, the Japanese word for a mountain when used in that sense. But the character may also be read in accordance with the two dialectical pronunciations of the two districts from whence the Japanese derived their knowledge of Chinese, viz., the Go-on , or the pronunciation of the Eastern State of Wu, and the Kan-on , or that of the city and neighbourhood of Singan Fu, the capital of Shensi. Thus the same character (Jj) may also be read Sen or San. VI PREFACE. Rut a Chinese character often has, in Chinese, many meanings, and it is therefore regarded in Japan as representing the corresponding Japanese words or expressions. For example, the Chinese character jfg Citing may be read “ the warp,” “ the veins,” u trade,” “ a book,” “ The Confucian Classics,” “ The Buddhist Sutras,” “ habitual,” “to pass,” “to strangle,” “to regulate.” This one, therefore, is also read by the Japanese as Tate, Sufi, Aldnai , Fund, Kei , Kid , Tsune , Furu , Kubiru , and Tadasu. From this system it is evident that unless the Cataloguer can recognize the meaning which the Author attaches to the character used, he may easily go astray, as is illustrated by the following incident. One of the best Japanese scholars we have was lately wishing to identify the original of a Japanese translation of an English novel. “ Well, at all events,” he said, holding the volume in his hands, “the first scene opens at Wapping.” When the discovery of the original proved that that port had no place on the page, he pointed out with j^erfect accuracy that the characters which he had read “ Wapping” might also mean “ To resume the thread of my discourse.” The same difficulty follows in regard to proper names. Authors can practically call themselves by any name they please within the wide range of the adopted system. In fact, it is scarcely an exaggeration to say that in numerous instances it is impossible to be sure of the correct pronunciation of a proper name without knowing how the bearer of it wishes it to be pronounced. So acutely is this difficulty felt by the Japanese themselves, that when the first Parliament was established at Tokio it was enacted that the names of Members should be pronounced according to the Chinese pronunciation in vogue in Japan. But there is a still further complexity in dealing with the names of Artists and Authors, for it is customary for these to assume at different periods of their careers different sobriquets, under any of which they may be known, and under any of which their sketch-books and writings may be launched into the world. For example, the well-known Artist Hokusai was known at different epochs as Kintaiska, Slranro, Tetsugoro, Tokitaro, Sori the Second, Hokusai Tatsumasa, Iiokusaiski, Katsushika Hokusai, Katsushika Taito, Kaishin, Tame-iclii, and Kan Kojin. And his sketch-books are progressively signed indifferently by any one of these assumed names. Authors of literary works are equally reckless in the adoption of aliases ; as, for instance, in the case of the greatest romancist of Japan, the celebrated Takizawa Kai, better recognized as Kiokutei Bakin, who at different periods was known to his friends and admirers as Teiyei Sanjin, Kuruwa no Makoto, Sakitsu, Saritsu, Kansai, Kaisai, Sliinten wo, Iviosai, Gushanjin, Gendo, and Chosakudo. But even this polyonymous Author is surpassed by Hayashi Gabo, who rejoiced in the possession of at least twenty-three different names. Another difficulty with which the Cataloguer has had to contend has been the question of the orthography to be adopted for the transliteration of Japanese words. Hitherto in this matter every European writer on Japanese has been a law unto PREFACE. vii himself. As an instance of this difficulty we may return to the Chinese word Clung in the sense of a Buddhist Sutra. In the first edition of Hepburn’s Japanese Dictionary (18G7) it is transcribed Kiyd, in the second edition (1886) it is written A7/o, and in Gubbins’s very useful little “ Dictionary of Chinese- Japanese Words in the Japanese Language” it is transliterated Rid. Again, in the same way the Japanese syllable is written respectively ZO, Zu, and Dzu ; and so on with almost every word admitting of ambiguity. In face of all these complications it is impossible that in the present work, which has necessarily been carried on through a number of years, inconsistencies should not occur, and that uniformity should have been always attained. The extent of the Supplement to this Catalogue is due to the fact that several considerable acquisitions were received too late to be included in the body of the Catalogue. And as it was felt that their omission would seriously affect its value, the publication of the present volume was postponed until a supplement containing the books referred to could be compiled and printed. For advice and assistance in the compilation of this, the largest and fullest Catalogue of Japanese Books ever printed in Europe, I owe a large debt of gratitude to Sir Ernest Satow, X.C.M.G., to Mr. Aston, to Mr. Chinsei Harahara, and to Kumagusu Minakata. ROBERT K. DOUGLAS. British Museum. January , 1898.
